stem: The nurse is performing a mandatory 15-minute assessment for a client in 4-point violent restraints. Based on the documentation, match each finding to the correct clinical action.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content: Patient: Marcus, 28 years old. Currently in leather restraints following an assault on staff. Time of application: 09:00. Nurse's Assessment (09:15): Client is yelling but limbs are currently immobile within the leather cuffs.

tabs.title: Neurovascular & Perfusion Tracking

rows.text: Radial pulse 2+, capillary refill 1.5 seconds, warm skin.
Radial pulse 1+, capillary refill 4.2 seconds, cool skin.
Client reports 'numbness and tingling' in the fingers.
The nurse can insert two fingers between the restraint and the skin.

columns.text: Indicative of compression / Loosen restraint immediately.

rationale.correct: Normal findings (c1) include strong pulses, warm skin, and rapid capillary refill (r1), as well as the 'two-finger' safety gap (r4). Abnormal findings (c2) indicative of nerve or vessel compression include weak pulses, cool skin, prolonged capillary refill (r2), and paresthesia (tingling/numbness/r3).
clinicalPearls: Violence restraints require monitoring every 15 minutes.
The 'Two-Finger Rule' prevents the restraint from being too tight.
A weak pulse distal to a restraint is a medical emergency; the restraint must be loosened immediately to prevent compartment syndrome or nerve damage.

questionTrap.trap: Thinking that 'Marcus is still shouting' is a reason to keep the restraint tight.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Even if the patient is violent, you CANNOT restrict their blood flow. Perfusion takes precedence over behavioral control.

mnemonic.title: The 5 Ps
mnemonic.expansion: Pain, Pulse, Pallor, Paresthesia, Paralysis. (Check these distal to EVERY restraint).
